name: Local Neighbourhood
description: The definitive map of the closest star systems to Earth, including all confirmed exoplanets.

nodes.name: Sol
nodes.description: The heart of our Solar System, Sol is a G-type main-sequence star (a yellow dwarf). It accounts for 99.8% of the system's total mass. Its energy, produced by nuclear fusion in its core, radiates outward, making life on Earth possible.

nodes.name: Mercury
nodes.description: The smallest planet and closest to the Sun. Mercury is a world of extremes, with scorching daytime temperatures (430°C) and frigid nights (-180°C). It has no real atmosphere, only a thin exosphere, and its cratered surface resembles Earth's Moon.

nodes.name: Venus
nodes.description: Earth's 'sister planet' in size, but a hellish world. Venus suffers from a runaway greenhouse effect, trapping heat under a thick, toxic atmosphere of CO2 and sulfuric acid clouds. Its surface pressure is 92 times that of Earth, and it's the hottest planet in the system.

nodes.name: Earth
nodes.description: The third planet from the Sun and the only known astronomical object to harbor life. It is an ocean world, with 71% of its surface covered in liquid water, protected by a strong magnetic field and a breathable nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere.

nodes.name: Luna
nodes.description: Earth's only natural satellite and the largest relative to its host planet in the Solar System. It is tidally locked, always showing the same face to Earth. Its cratered, airless surface is composed of dark volcanic 'maria' and bright, ancient highlands.

nodes.name: Mars
nodes.description: The fourth planet, known as the 'Red Planet' due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface. It's a cold desert world with a very thin CO2 atmosphere, polar ice caps, and the largest volcano (Olympus Mons) and canyon (Valles Marineris) in the Solar System.

nodes.name: Phobos
nodes.description: The larger and innermost of Mars's two moons. It is a small, lumpy, and heavily cratered body, thought to be a captured asteroid. Phobos orbits so close to Mars that it will either crash into the planet or be torn apart into a ring in about 50 million years.

nodes.name: Deimos
nodes.description: The smaller and outer of Mars's two moons. Like its sibling Phobos, Deimos is a small, dark, and irregularly shaped body, likely a captured C-type asteroid. Its surface is smoother than Phobos's, as many of its craters are filled with fine dust (regolith).

nodes.name: The Main Belt
nodes.description: A torus-shaped region of space between Mars and Jupiter, occupied by millions of asteroids. This is leftover material from the early Solar System that was prevented from forming a planet by Jupiter's immense gravity. The largest object in the belt is the dwarf planet Ceres.

nodes.name: Jupiter
nodes.description: The fifth planet and the largest in the Solar System. This gas giant is more than twice as massive as all other planets combined. It's known for its colorful cloud bands of ammonia ice and the Great Red Spot, a giant storm that has raged for centuries.

nodes.name: Jupiter's Rings
nodes.description: A faint ring system composed of three main parts: an inner 'halo', a bright 'main' ring, and an outer 'gossamer' ring. Unlike Saturn's icy rings, Jupiter's are made of small, dark dust particles, likely kicked up from its small inner moons by meteoroid impacts.

nodes.name: Io
nodes.description: The innermost Galilean moon, Io is the most volcanically active body in the Solar System. It is caught in a tidal 'tug-of-war' between Jupiter and the other moons, which flexes its interior and powers hundreds of volcanoes that erupt sulfur and lava.

nodes.name: Europa
nodes.description: A smooth, ice-covered world with a young surface crisscrossed by cracks and streaks. It is a prime candidate for life, as evidence strongly suggests a deep, liquid saltwater ocean exists beneath its 15-25 km thick ice shell, kept warm by tidal heating.

nodes.name: Ganymede
nodes.description: The largest moon in the Solar System, even larger than the planet Mercury. Ganymede is a differentiated icy world and is the only moon known to have its own magnetic field. Its surface has both dark, ancient, cratered regions and lighter, younger, grooved terrain.

nodes.name: Callisto
nodes.description: The outermost Galilean moon, Callisto has the oldest and most heavily cratered surface in the Solar System, indicating a lack of geological activity. It is a geologically 'dead' world, composed of roughly equal parts rock and ice. It may also hide a subsurface ocean.

nodes.name: Saturn
nodes.description: The sixth planet and the second-largest, Saturn is a gas giant famous for its spectacular ring system. It is the least dense planet—it would float in water. Its atmosphere is a pale yellow, striped with bands of ammonia ice clouds and powerful winds.

nodes.name: Saturn's Rings
nodes.description: The most extensive and complex ring system in the Solar System. The rings are not solid but are made of billions of particles of water ice, with some rock and dust, ranging in size from a grain of sand to a house. They are incredibly thin, perhaps only 10 meters thick.

nodes.name: Titan
nodes.description: Saturn's largest moon and the only moon with a thick, Earth-like atmosphere (though it's 95% nitrogen and toxic). Its surface is -179°C, cold enough for liquid methane and ethane to form rivers, lakes, and seas in a 'hydrological' cycle similar to Earth's water cycle.

nodes.name: Enceladus
nodes.description: A small, bright white icy moon that is one of the most compelling places to search for life. It ejects massive plumes of water, ice, and organic molecules from 'tiger stripes' near its south pole, revealing a global subsurface ocean of liquid saltwater.

nodes.name: Mimas
nodes.description: The smallest and innermost of Saturn's major moons, Mimas is nicknamed the 'Death Star' moon. It is dominated by the Herschel crater, a massive impact basin 139 km wide—nearly a third of the moon's own diameter—that almost shattered the icy body.

nodes.name: Rhea
nodes.description: Saturn's second-largest moon, Rhea is a heavily cratered, airless body of ice and rock. Its surface is ancient, with one hemisphere being brighter and more cratered than the other. Its surface also features bright, 'wispy' streaks, which are exposed ice cliffs.

nodes.name: Iapetus
nodes.description: Saturn's 'yin-yang' moon, Iapetus is famous for its dramatic two-tone coloration. Its leading hemisphere is as dark as coal, while its trailing hemisphere is as bright as fresh snow. It also possesses a massive, 20-km-high equatorial ridge.

nodes.name: Uranus
nodes.description: The seventh planet, an ice giant tipped on its side. Uranus rotates at a 98-degree angle, likely from a past collision, causing extreme seasons where its poles face the Sun for 42 years at a time. Its blue-green color comes from methane in its H-He atmosphere.

nodes.name: Uranus' Rings
nodes.description: Uranus is surrounded by 13 known rings. Unlike Saturn's bright, icy rings, these are extremely dark and narrow, composed of particles as dark as coal, likely water ice mixed with radiation-processed organic compounds. They were the first to be discovered after Saturn's.

nodes.name: Titania
nodes.description: The largest of Uranus's moons. This icy, rocky world shows signs of past geological activity. Its surface is cut by a system of enormous canyons and fault valleys, some stretching for 1,000 miles, indicating its interior expanded and cracked the crust long ago.

nodes.name: Oberon
nodes.description: The outermost and second-largest of the major Uranian moons. Oberon has the most ancient and heavily cratered surface of Uranus's moons, showing little sign of past geological activity. Its dark, reddish surface is covered in impact craters, some with bright rays of ice.

nodes.name: Ariel
nodes.description: The brightest and youngest-surfaced of Uranus's moons. Ariel shows clear signs of geologic activity, with vast, interconnected canyons and fault valleys. Smooth plains suggest that 'cryovolcanism' (ice volcanoes) may have once resurfaced parts of the moon.

nodes.name: Neptune
nodes.description: The eighth and most distant planet, Neptune is a dark, cold ice giant whipped by supersonic winds. It has a vivid blue color from methane in its atmosphere. It was the first planet found through mathematical prediction rather than direct observation.

nodes.name: Neptune's Rings
nodes.description: Neptune is encircled by five faint, dark rings. They are notable for containing unstable, bright clumps of dust called 'arcs,' which are thought to be held in place by the gravity of the small moon Galatea. These rings are dusty and relatively young.

nodes.name: Triton
nodes.description: Neptune's largest moon and likely a captured Kuiper Belt Object. It is one of the coldest worlds known (-235°C), yet it is geologically active, with geysers of nitrogen gas erupting from its icy surface. It orbits Neptune 'backwards' in a retrograde orbit.

nodes.name: Kuiper Belt
nodes.description: A vast, doughnut-shaped ring of icy bodies beyond the orbit of Neptune, from about 30 to 50 AU. It is a reservoir of comets and contains many dwarf planets, including Pluto. This is a cold, distant region containing remnants from the formation of the Solar System.

nodes.name: Pluto
nodes.description: A dwarf planet in the Kuiper Belt, formerly classified as the ninth planet. It is a complex world of ice mountains and frozen nitrogen plains. Its highly eccentric orbit sometimes brings it closer to the Sun than Neptune. It has five known moons.

nodes.name: Charon
nodes.description: Pluto's largest moon, so large (half of Pluto's diameter) that the two are considered a binary dwarf planet system. They orbit a common barycenter located in the space between them. Charon is tidally locked to Pluto, so they both always show the same face to each other.

nodes.name: International Space Station
nodes.description: The premier research facility in LEO. A modular habitation of modules and trusses.

nodes.name: Tiangong Station
nodes.description: A T-shaped modular station. Modern, automated, and efficient.
nodes.gmNotes: China's space station. Uses Hall Effect thrusters for station keeping.

nodes.name: Lunar Gateway
nodes.description: A small station in a Near-Rectilinear Halo Orbit around the Moon. Staging point for surface landings.
nodes.gmNotes: The bridge to the surface. High radiation environment outside.

nodes.name: Ascension Heavy Lifter
nodes.description: A shimmering stainless steel tower. This reusable heavy lifter is capable of Single-Stage-To-Orbit with 100t of cargo. Uses 30 massive Methalox Raptors.
nodes.gmNotes: The workhorse of the new era. Capable of landing on Mars or Earth.

nodes.name: Alpha Centauri Barycenter
nodes.description: The common center of mass for the Alpha Centauri A/B binary pair. These two Sun-like stars orbit each other in a close, 80-year dance.

nodes.name: Alpha Centauri A (Rigil Kentaurus)
nodes.description: The primary star, a G-type star almost identical to our Sun (just slightly larger and brighter). From its perspective, Alpha Centauri B would be a dazzlingly bright 'second sun' that swings close and far every 80 years.

nodes.name: Alpha Centauri B (Toliman)
nodes.description: The secondary star, a K-type orange dwarf. It is slightly smaller and cooler than our Sun. Its highly elliptical 80-year orbit brings it as close as Saturn and as far as Neptune from Star A.

nodes.name: Proxima Centauri (Alpha Centauri C)
nodes.description: The third star of the system and our Sun's closest neighbor. Proxima is a tiny, dim M-type red dwarf in a vast, 550,000-year orbit around the central A-B pair. It is a violent 'flare star,' frequently lashing its inner planets with radiation.

nodes.name: Proxima Centauri d
nodes.description: The innermost planet of Proxima. This tiny 'Sub-Earth' orbits in just 5 days, placing it too close for liquid water. It is a small, scorched, and likely airless rocky world, tidally locked and blasted by the star's frequent, powerful flares.

nodes.name: Proxima Centauri b
nodes.description: An Earth-sized world orbiting within Proxima's habitable zone. It is tidally locked, so one side is in endless day and the other in endless night. It may be a 'cold eyeball' planet, with a region of liquid water in a 'terminator' ring between the two extremes.

nodes.name: Proxima Centauri c
nodes.description: A 'Mini-Neptune' or 'Super-Earth' orbiting far from its star, about 1.5 AU out. It takes over 5 years to complete one orbit. It is a frigid world, well beyond the system's frost line, and has likely retained a thick, primordial atmosphere of hydrogen and helium.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1
nodes.description: An ultra-cool M-type red dwarf, TRAPPIST-1 is barely larger than the planet Jupiter. It is extremely old (7.6 Gyr) and has a very low temperature. Despite its small size, it hosts a remarkable, compact system of seven Earth-sized terrestrial planets.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 b
nodes.description: The innermost planet, TRAPPIST-1 b orbits so close to its star that its 'year' is only 1.5 Earth days. It is tidally locked and scorched by radiation, making it far too hot for liquid water. It is likely a barren, airless rock, similar to Mercury.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 c
nodes.description: The second planet, 'c', is another tidally locked world, likely a 'hot eyeball' planet. Its dayside is perpetually baked by the star, creating a runaway greenhouse effect. It is thought to be a 'sister' to Venus: rocky, but with a crushing, toxic atmosphere.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 d
nodes.description: The third planet and the first to be located within the star's 'habitable zone.' It's tidally locked, so one side is in endless day and the other in endless night. It's a 'cold eyeball' world, where liquid water might exist only in a narrow 'terminator' ring between the two extremes.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 e
nodes.description: This planet is the 'sweet spot' of the TRAPPIST-1 system. It is almost exactly the size of Earth, rocky, and orbits squarely in the middle of the habitable zone. It receives a similar amount of light as Earth and is a prime candidate for hosting liquid water on its surface.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 f
nodes.description: Another large, rocky planet in the habitable zone. It's slightly larger than Earth and on the colder side, receiving about as much light as Mars. It is likely a 'cold eyeball' world, or a global 'water-world' covered in a thick ocean under a CO2-rich atmosphere.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 g
nodes.description: The largest planet in the system, 'g' is a 'Super-Earth' or 'Mini-Neptune' located at the cold, outer edge of the habitable zone. It is likely a cold, icy world that has held onto a thick hydrogen/helium atmosphere, making it uninhabitable on the surface.

nodes.name: TRAPPIST-1 h
nodes.description: The outermost and coldest planet in the system, 'h' is a small, frozen ice-ball. It orbits well beyond the habitable zone, receiving very little energy from its faint star. It is most likely a 'Pluto-like' world with a thin nitrogen exosphere.

nodes.name: Luyten 726-8 Barycenter
nodes.description: Center of mass for the binary pair of variable red dwarfs.

nodes.name: UV Ceti (Luyten 726-8 B)
nodes.description: The prototype for 'Flare Stars'. It can increase in brightness by 75 times in a matter of seconds due to extreme magnetic activity.

nodes.name: Procyon Barycenter
nodes.description: The center of mass for the Procyon system, located just 11.4 light years from Sol.

nodes.name: Procyon B
nodes.description: A faint white dwarf companion, consisting of degenerate matter. It is slightly smaller than Earth but contains 60% of the Sun's mass.

nodes.name: 61 Cygni Barycenter
nodes.description: A famous binary pair of orange dwarfs.

nodes.name: Struve 2398 Barycenter
nodes.description: A binary system of two red dwarfs orbiting about 56 AU apart.

nodes.name: Luhman 16 Barycenter
nodes.description: The third closest system to the Sun, but invisible to the naked eye. A pair of brown dwarfs dancing in the dark.

nodes.name: Luhman 16 B
nodes.description: A T-type brown dwarf known for its patchy clouds of molten iron and silicates, causing significant brightness variations.

nodes.name: Lacaille 9352
nodes.description: A bright Red Dwarf (M0.5V), roughly half the mass of the Sun. It hosts a system of super-earths.

nodes.name: Lacaille 9352 c
nodes.description: A massive Super-Earth orbiting near the inner edge of the habitable zone.

nodes.name: Lacaille 9352 d
nodes.description: A candidate Super-Earth located squarely within the habitable zone. If confirmed, it is a prime target for life.
